repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
## Problem
Two cases lsp.enable() won't work in the first FileType event
1. lsp.enable luals inside FileType or ftplugin/lua.lua, then:
```
nvim a.lua
```

2. lsp.enable luals inside FileType or ftplugin/lua.lua, then:
```
nvim -> :edit a.lua -> :mksession! | restart +qa! so Session.vim
```


## Solution
Currently `v:vim_did_enter` is used to detected two cases:
1. "maunally enabled" (lsp.enable() or `:lsp enable`)
2. "inside FileType event"

To detect 2. correctly we use did_filetype().

comment_data.body: I'm confused, why do we need to execute all of this code with `clear_notrace`?
i'm not sure what this does. i use it because i see it's used in before_each, maybe it can be reomoved
I use `n.clear()` now. It seems not necessary. https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/14226

based on your PR description (and test code), is this a more correct test name:

```suggestion
    it('in first FileType event (on startup)', function()
```
this is pretty nasty, can the `--cmd` just do a `require('test.functional.plugin.lsp.testutil').create_server_definition` or something like that?

> `require('test.functional.plugin.lsp.testutil').create_server_definition` or something like that?

Some test runner dependencies like busted are needed to require this file. I tried to do this by copy package.path to child, but failed to make it work. Since test runner did some other setup in cmake/build.zig.

This looks ugly, but it basically did the same thing as `exec_lua(create_server_definition)` (`string.dump` a function then passed it into child).

`base64` is only used to avoid some char mess up the cmdline.
Maybe I can also use `vim.text.hexencode`.. it's usable in test runner,  
Or..... `string.dump` to a tmpfile, then `loadfile` from it.

comment_regular_data.body: Why would you do that in the first place? The sole purpose of `lsp.enable` is to set up the autocommand to `lsp.start()` the client.

> Why would you do that in the first place? The sole purpose of `lsp.enable` is to set up the autocommand to `lsp.start()` the client.

I see https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/33702 close https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/33116 but maybe it's not designed to be address nest "FileType" use case? I can close this pr if this is unsupported.

(It used to work for me because another lazy.nvim bug to trigger FileType event twice...)

> I see https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/33702 close https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/33116 but maybe it's not designed to be address nest "FileType" use case? 

Right, I remember now; ignore my comment as irrelevant.

title: fix: lsp.enable() don't work correctly inside FileType event
